title: How the BRRRR Method Compares to Fix-and-Flip Investing
excerpt: Curious how the BRRRR method stacks up against the classic fix-and-flip strategy? Here’s a breakdown of how BRRRR works, its pros and cons, and how it compares to flipping houses for investors focused on buying, renovating, and selling properties.

content.text: The BRRRR method is a real estate investment strategy designed to help you build a portfolio with minimal capital tied up in each deal. Unlike fix-and-flip, where you sell the property after renovation, BRRRR focuses on long-term rental income and equity growth. The process involves five steps: Buy, Rehab, Rent, Refinance, and Repeat.

items: Buy: Target distressed or undervalued properties, much like a fix-and-flip. Aim to keep your purchase price plus renovation costs below 75% of the after-repair value (ARV).
Rehab: Renovate the property for maximum ROI. Focus on improvements that boost value and appeal to renters—think kitchens, bathrooms, paint, and curb appeal.
Rent: Fill the property with qualified tenants. Strong rental income can help increase appraised value and make refinancing easier.

Refinance: Once the property is stabilized with tenants, refinance based on the new, higher value. Ideally, you pull out most or all of your original investment—similar to getting your flip profits, but you keep the property.
Repeat: Use the cash from your refinance to buy your next property and repeat the process.
Exit Strategy: Fix-and-flip investors sell after renovation; BRRRR investors keep the property as a rental.
Cash Flow: Flipping provides a lump-sum profit; BRRRR builds long-term rental income and equity.
Capital Recycling: Both methods aim to get your investment back, but BRRRR does it via refinancing instead of a sale.
Management: Flipping ends with the sale; BRRRR requires ongoing property management or a trusted manager.

content.text: Suppose you buy a property for $400,000 and spend $200,000 on rehab. The ARV is $850,000. You invest $80,000 as a down payment and finance the rest. After renovation and leasing, you refinance at 75% ARV ($637,500), pay off your original loan, and pocket $117,500—enough to fund your next deal, just like flipping, but you keep the asset.
Pros and Cons for Fix-and-Flip Investors

items: Pros: Leverage your renovation skills for long-term wealth, recycle capital for more deals, and generate rental income.
Cons: Requires property management, accurate projections, and a strong network. If the ARV or rent falls short, you may not recoup your investment as quickly as with a flip.
Run your numbers up front: Know your rehab costs, rental potential, and ARV before you buy.
Don’t over-improve: Stick to renovations that boost value and rentability.
Build a strong team: Agents, lenders, contractors, and property managers are key.
Plan for management: Decide if you’ll self-manage or hire a pro.
Traditional Fix-and-Flip: Buy, renovate, and sell for a quick profit—no long-term management.
Buy-and-Hold: Skip the refinance and hold rentals for long-term appreciation.
Syndication: Invest passively in larger deals managed by professionals.

content.text: If you’re already skilled at finding and renovating properties, BRRRR lets you build a rental portfolio while recycling your capital—an appealing next step for experienced fix-and-flip investors ready for long-term wealth.
